content: i  you are going to make mistakes there is no didn t miss a yarn over easily fixed on the next getting around this incontrovertible fact about purl row by just pulling up the strand in lace knitting your spouse or roommate or between the stitches where it belonged and sister or cat is going to distract you and you will placing that strand on the needle i look at the forget a stitch or a yarn over you will realize previous row and make sure everything looks this much later than you would like but you okay and the yarn overs are forming the proper will learn more about knitting from finding and pattern most lace shawls have pretty obvious fixing one mistake than knitting 50 row geometric lines so i make sure that if the correctly pattern has 5 diagonal yarn over holes ashton © 2015 by dee o keefe  dee okeefe@ymail com  dee o keefe designs worsted weight version page 12 the nice thing about using worsted weight yarn is that ashton will knit up a lot quicker since there are fewer row work all charts with us 8 5 0 mm needles and bind off with a us 10 6 0 mm needle the yarn i used for the shawlette pictured to the right is neighborhood fiber company studio worsted patterson park colorway for a worsted weight shawlette measuring approximately 54 x 27 137 x 69 cm chart 2 is worked only 2x and all other charts are worked 1x approximately 375-400 yards 343-366 m of worsted weight yarn is required for this size if you wish to make a larger ashton than that note that each additional chart 2 repeat worked will use about 115 yards 142 m more if you are adding more leaves see advanced extra border leaves option on page 8 consider each extra row of leaves another jump up in size so figure you would use another 125 yards 114 m on top of any extra yardage used for additional chart 2 repeats worked stitch counts for 2x size the stitch count after the final row of chart 1 is the same for both fingering and worsted weight versions 59 stitches after the first repeat of chart 2 there are 83 stitches after the second repeat of chart 2 there are 107 stitches at the end of chart 2a there are 131 stitches if you like to check stitch counts at the end of every row for charts 1 2 and 2a each successive right-side row adds 4 stitches to the stitch count at the end of the previous right-side row all wrong-side row will have the same count as the previous right-side row as no stitches are added on these row charts 3 and 4 are a bit trickier because some row add more stitches +8 than the usual 4 and some don t add any at all here are the end-of-row counts for chart 3 row
